questions.text: A young boy feels that dirt has hung onto him whenever he passes through the dirty street. He knows that there is no such thing after he has cleaned once, but he is not satisfied and compelled to think so. Although he knows that this is completely irrational but he can't control his thoughts. It gives him anxiety and a depressive mood. Which of the following is wrong about his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The boy's repetitive, intrusive thoughts and compulsive washing behaviour are classic features of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD).

Definition and Key Features:

  • OCD is characterised by obsessions (recurrent, intrusive thoughts or images) and/or compulsions (repetitive behaviours or mental acts aimed at reducing distress).
  • The thoughts are ego-dystonic (experienced as alien and inconsistent with the person’s values) (Option A), causing marked distress.

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • OCD is associated with serotonin dysfunction (Option B) in the cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical circuits.
  • Genetic and environmental factors also contribute.

Clinical Features:

  • Persistent, unwanted thoughts about contamination (obsessions).
  • Compulsive washing rituals to reduce anxiety (compulsions).
  • Insight: The boy realises his thoughts are irrational but feels compelled to act.
  • Depression and anxiety are common comorbidities in OCD patients.

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis is clinical, based on DSM-5 criteria.
  • Severity can be measured using the Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS).

Management:

  • First-line treatment: SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine, sertraline) targeting serotonin imbalance.
  • Psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT), particularly Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) (Option C), is highly effective.

questions.text: A junior resident in the general surgery department spends 45 minutes washing his hands before every operation, feeling compelled to do so repeatedly despite being scolded by seniors for wasting time. He knows that this is unreasonable, but he cannot control it, and it causes him significant anxiety and a low mood. Which of the following statements about his condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reality testing is preserved in OCD, differentiating it from psychotic illnesses. The case describes Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), where the individual experiences persistent, unwanted thoughts about contamination and engages in compulsive washing rituals to relieve distress.

Definition and Key Features:

  • OCD involves intrusive, repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and ritualistic behaviours (compulsions) aimed at reducing the associated anxiety.
  • The thoughts and behaviours are ego-dystonic (Option A), meaning they are perceived by the patient as excessive or irrational, causing internal conflict.

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Serotonergic dysfunction is believed to play a key role, involving circuits within the orbitofrontal cortex, caudate nucleus, and thalamus.
  • Environmental and psychological stressors can contribute to symptom exacerbation.

Clinical Features:

  • Persistent washing rituals in response to fears of contamination.
  • Recognition of the irrational nature of the fears and behaviours (insight present). (Option C)
  • Judgment remains intact, and patients are fully aware of reality. (Option B)
  • Significant emotional distress and functional impairment due to these symptoms.

Investigation and Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis based on DSM-5 criteria.
  • Use of the Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS) for severity assessment.

Management:

  • CBT with Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the mainstay of behavioural treatment.
  • SSRIs are the first-line pharmacotherapy to target the underlying serotonergic imbalance.

questions.text:
Identify the OCD-related disorders as per ICD-11:
1. Hoarding disorder
2. Trichotillomania
3. Hypochondriasis
4. Olfactory reference syndrome
questions.solution:
Explanation:

ICD-11 includes several OCD-related disorders based on shared features such as repetitive thoughts and compulsive behaviours:

questions.text: Match the following neurotransmitters with their roles in OCD:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glutamate (1-D): Emerging evidence shows its role in modulating the cortico-striatal-thalamo-cortical circuits involved in OCD.
  • Serotonin (2-B): Core neurotransmitter linked to OCD pathophysiology and target of first-line SSRIs.
  • Dopamine (3-C): Involved in the compulsive and motor aspects of rituals seen in OCD.
  • Norepinephrine (4-A): Associated with heightened arousal and vigilance in anxiety-related conditions, which overlaps with OCD features.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with motor tics (eye blinking, shoulder shrugging) and vocal tics (throat clearing). His parents also report the sudden onset of obsessive-compulsive behaviours that appear to worsen during winter and early spring. Which of the following conditions should be carefully evaluated in this child before proceeding with the management of the tic disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child's sudden onset or worsening of tics and OCD-like symptoms suggests the possibility of PANDAS (Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections).

Definition and Key Features:

  • PANDAS involves the abrupt appearance of tic disorders and/or obsessive-compulsive symptoms in children, temporally related to Group A β-hemolytic streptococcal (GABHS) infections.
  • Symptoms tend to wax and wane, often worsening in winter and early spring when streptococcal infections are common.

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Proposed autoimmune mechanism: antibodies produced against streptococcal antigens cross-react with neuronal tissues in the basal ganglia, leading to neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Clinical Features:

  • Sudden onset of motor and vocal tics.
  • New or worsening obsessive-compulsive symptoms.
  • Symptom exacerbation following streptococcal infections.

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Throat culture and antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers to confirm recent streptococcal infection.
  • Diagnosis of PANDAS is clinical but supported by laboratory evidence of GABHS.

Management:

  • Antibiotic therapy (e.g., penicillin or azithromycin) to eradicate streptococcal infection.
  • Standard treatments for tic disorders (e.g., antipsychotics) and OCD (e.g., SSRIs, CBT) can also be employed.

Explanation of Other Options:

Environmental allergies (Option A): Incorrect because allergies do not cause abrupt-onset tics and OCD behaviours linked to infection. Allergies are associated with seasonal allergic rhinitis, not with neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Rett Disorder (Option B): Incorrect as it involves neurodevelopmental regression and stereotypic hand movements, not sudden onset of tics or OCD behaviours.

Autism Spectrum Disorder (Option C): Incorrect because autism typically features social communication deficits and repetitive behaviours, not sudden tic emergence linked to infections.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is described by colleagues as excessively devoted to work, spending hours perfecting every small detail, and unwilling to delegate tasks because others don't meet his standards. He is also inflexible in matters of morality and ethics and has difficulty discarding old, worn-out items. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's rigid perfectionism, inflexibility, and preoccupation with orderliness are hallmark features of Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder (OCPD).

Definition and Key Features:

  • OCPD is a pervasive pattern of preoccupation with orderliness, perfectionism, and control, at the expense of flexibility and efficiency.
  • Unlike OCD, which involves intrusive obsessions and compulsions, OCPD behaviours are ego-syntonic-they are consistent with the patient's self-image.

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Traits typically emerge in early adulthood and are thought to be shaped by environmental factors and learned behaviour rather than neurochemical imbalances.

Clinical Features:

  • Excessive devotion to work and productivity, often at the expense of leisure and relationships.
  • Inflexibility about morality, ethics, and values.
  • Hoarding worn-out objects despite no practical value.
  • Reluctance to delegate tasks unless others submit to their exact standards.

Diagnosis and Investigations:

  • Diagnosis is clinical, based on DSM-5 criteria for personality disorders.
  • No laboratory investigations are required.

Management:

  • Psychotherapy, especially cognitive-behavioural approaches, can help address rigid perfectionism and improve interpersonal functioning.
  • Pharmacotherapy may be used for associated anxiety or depressive symptoms.

Explanation of other options:

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (Option B): Incorrect because OCD involves recurrent, intrusive obsessions and/or compulsions, not a lifelong pattern of perfectionism and inflexibility.

Hoarding Disorder (Option C): Incorrect, as hoarding in OCPD is typically related to perfectionism, not to distressing thoughts or compulsions. In Hoarding Disorder, patients experience significant distress and difficulty discarding items due to perceived future need.

Schizophrenia (Option D): Incorrect because schizophrenia involves psychotic symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, disorganised thinking, and negative symptoms, not perfectionism or rigid orderliness.

questions.text:
Obsessions are repetitive, intrusive mental phenomena that can occur in which of the following forms?
1. Thoughts
2. Words
3. Images
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Obsessions are recurrent, unwanted, intrusive experiences that cause significant anxiety and distress. They can take the form of thoughts, words, and images, all of which the patient recognises as irrational but cannot control.

Definition and Key Features:

  • Obsessions are ego-dystonic, meaning they are recognised as inconsistent with one’s values.
  • Common themes include contamination, aggression, sex, and orderliness.
  • They can be experienced as thoughts (e.g., “I might harm someone”), images (e.g., disturbing mental pictures), or words (e.g., mentally repeating distressing phrases).

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Linked to hyperactivity in the cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical circuitry, involving serotonin dysregulation.
  • Stress and personal vulnerabilities contribute to symptom severity.

Clinical Features:

  • Intrusive, unwanted thoughts or images causing marked anxiety.
  • Compulsions may be present to neutralise these obsessions, such as handwashing to reduce contamination fears.

Diagnosis and Management:

  • Clinical diagnosis based on DSM-5 criteria.
  • CBT with Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is a first-line psychological treatment.
  • SSRIs are pharmacological mainstays for targeting serotonin dysregulation.

choices.text: Ego-syntonic, because they are aligned with his internal desires
Ego-dystonic, because they conflict with his sense of self
A sign of psychosis with external control over his mind

questions.text: A 28-year-old man describes repetitive, intrusive thoughts of harming his loved ones, which he finds extremely distressing and inconsistent with his personal values. He states, "I know these thoughts come from my mind, and I'm not being forced to think them by anyone else." Which of the following best characterises the nature of these thoughts?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ego-dystonic thoughts are those that the patient recognises as intrusive, unwanted, and inconsistent with their personal values and self-image, as seen in this case of intrusive, distressing obsessions.

Definition and Key Features:

  • In OCD, obsessions are typically experienced as alien and distressing, even though the patient knows they originate within their own mind.
  • This recognition that thoughts are self-generated but in conflict with core beliefs is the hallmark of ego-dystonic experiences.

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Thought to involve dysregulation of serotonin and dysfunction in the cortico-striatal-thalamo-cortical circuitry.
  • OCD patients have intact reality testing, distinguishing these thoughts from true psychotic delusions.

Clinical Features:

  • Obsessions: Intrusive, repetitive thoughts recognised as irrational.
  • Compulsions: Behaviours performed to reduce distress caused by obsessions.
  • Insight: Maintained-patients recognise these thoughts as unwanted and not externally imposed.

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis using DSM-5 criteria.
  • Tools like the Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS) help assess severity.

Management:

  • CBT with Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP).
  • SSRIs are first-line pharmacological therapy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ego-syntonic (Option A): Incorrect because ego-syntonic thoughts are in harmony with the patient's values and desires, unlike the distressing nature of these thoughts.

Ego-ideal (Option C): Incorrect; refers to internalised standards and aspirations, not intrusive, distressing thoughts.

Sign of psychosis (Option D): Incorrect, as psychotic symptoms involve a loss of reality testing and external attribution (e.g., thought insertion), which is not present in OCD.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student presents with repetitive handwashing rituals that he feels compelled to perform for long periods each day. He reports these behaviours began in his late teens and are driven by intrusive fears of contamination, which he recognises as unreasonable but cannot stop. Which of the following best describes the typical age range of peak incidence for the onset of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient's symptoms of repetitive, intrusive fears of contamination and compulsive washing are classic for Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), which typically has its peak incidence of onset between 15 and 25 years.

Definition and Key Features:

  • Obsessions: Intrusive, unwanted thoughts (e.g., contamination fears).
  • Compulsions: Repetitive behaviours (e.g., handwashing) aimed at reducing distress.
  • Ego-dystonic: Patients recognise these thoughts and behaviours as excessive.

Epidemiology:

  • The peak incidence of OCD onset is in late adolescence to early adulthood (15–25 years).
  • Males may experience the onset slightly earlier (childhood or early teens), while females more commonly present in later teens or early twenties.

Clinical Features:

  • The patient experiences significant anxiety and distress about contamination.
  • Repetitive washing rituals interfere with daily functioning.
  • Symptoms are not due to psychosis (insight is present).

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis based on DSM-5 criteria.
  • No lab tests are needed to confirm OCD.

Management:

  • First-line treatment: CBT with Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP).
  • SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine, sertraline) target serotonergic dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions generally presents with the latest average age of onset compared to the others?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) has a later mean age of onset than the other listed disorders, typically around 20 years.

Comparison of Typical Age of Onset:

  • Anorexia Nervosa (Option A): Usually begins in mid-adolescence, within 5 years of menarche for most females.
  • Autism Spectrum Disorder (Asperger's subtype) (Option B): Symptoms typically present in early childhood (by age 3).
  • Social Anxiety Disorder (Social Phobia) (Option D): Usually emerges after puberty, typically in the mid-teen years.
  • Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder: Mean onset is in late adolescence to early adulthood, around 20 years.

choices.text: There is a bimodal age of onset, with peaks at ages 12-14 years and 20-22 years
Brain imaging studies show morphological changes in basal ganglia structures
First-degree relatives of OCD patients have a higher-than-normal incidence of psychiatric disorders
Predominance of phobic ruminative ideas and absence of compulsions is associated with a poor prognosis

questions.text: In evaluating Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), which of the following statements is least accurate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The statement that the predominance of phobic ruminative ideas and the absence of compulsions is a poor prognostic factor is incorrect. These features are generally linked to a better prognosis in OCD.

Key Concepts:

  • OCD has a bimodal peak onset (Option A) in adolescence (12-14 years) and early adulthood (20-22 years).
  • Neuroimaging shows structural changes in the basal ganglia (Option B) (especially the caudate nucleus), thalamus, and orbitofrontal cortex.
  • First-degree relatives of patients with OCD have an increased prevalence of OCD and other anxiety-related disorders. (Option C)
  • Phobic ruminative obsessions without compulsions tend to have a favourable prognosis, often a milder course, and better treatment response.

choices.text: Cognitive and behavioural strategies are more effective than serotonergic antidepressants
Group therapy is less effective than individual therapy
More frequent therapy sessions are associated with improved outcomes
Treatment of any kind is more successful if compulsions are present

questions.text: Regarding the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder, which of the following is most correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of compulsions in OCD typically leads to a better treatment response because compulsions provide a behavioural target for therapy.

Key Concepts:

  • Compulsions are ritualistic behaviours (e.g., washing, checking) that are easier to identify and modify with CBT, enhancing treatment efficacy.
  • SSRIs and CBT have comparable effectiveness in OCD, particularly when compulsions are present.
  • More frequent therapy sessions alone do not guarantee better outcomes-treatment duration and adherence are more important predictors of success.

Explanation of Other Options:

Option A (CBT vs SSRIs): Incorrect because both are equally effective for OCD, especially when combined.

Option B (Group vs individual therapy): Incorrect, as studies have shown similar outcomes for both formats in OCD.

Option C (Therapy frequency): Incorrect since session frequency alone does not predict outcome; rather, it's the quality, duration, and patient engagement that matter.

choices.text: It typically presents with an abrupt, acute onset
Patients usually present to a doctor soon after symptom onset
There is often a long duration of untreated illness
OCD has a rapidly progressive, deteriorating course

questions.text: Which of the following is generally true about the clinical presentation and help-seeking behaviour of patients with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

OCD is characterised by a long duration of untreated illness-patients often suffer in silence for many years before seeking help.

Key Concepts:

  • The ego-dystonic nature of obsessions and associated shame can delay seeking treatment, with many patients presenting after 5-10 years of symptoms.
  • Symptoms often emerge in adolescence or early adulthood, but the onset of comorbid depression may finally prompt help-seeking.

Explanation of Other Options:

Option A (Acute onset): OCD usually has an insidious onset, although some report sudden symptom onset.

Option B (Early presentation): Many patients delay seeking help due to embarrassment or normalisation of their compulsive behaviours.

Option D (Chronic deteriorating course): While OCD is often chronic, it is not necessarily rapidly progressive or deteriorating - symptoms may wax and wane.

choices.text: Poor insight into the irrational nature of obsessions and compulsions

questions.text: In the prognosis of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), which of the following features is generally considered to be associated with a better outcome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A family history of OCD does not have a significant impact on prognosis and is not considered a poor prognostic factor.

Key Concepts:

  • Poor prognostic factors in OCD include:
    • Early childhood onset (Option A)
    • Male gender
    • Poor insight (Option B)
    • Presence of bizarre compulsions
    • Comorbid major depression (Option D)
    • Need for hospitalisation
    • Presence of schizotypal personality traits or other personality disorders
  • Good prognostic indicators:
    • Good premorbid functioning
    • A precipitating stressful event
    • Episodic symptom course
    • No comorbid personality disorder

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent, involuntary vocal outbursts and brief, sudden movements like eye blinking and shoulder shrugging. He also reports repetitive throat clearing. Which of the following disorders is most strongly associated with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The symptoms of motor and vocal tics described are characteristic of Tourette's Disorder.

Definition and Key Features:

  • Tourette's disorder involves multiple motor tics (e.g., eye blinking, shoulder shrugging) and at least one vocal tic (e.g., throat clearing, grunting).
  • Symptoms must be present for at least 1 year, with onset before age 18.

Aetiology and Pathophysiology:

  • Thought to involve dysfunction in the cortico-striatal-thalamo-cortical circuits, similar to OCD.
  • Genetic factors play a significant role, with strong familial clustering.

Clinical Features:

  • Sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements or vocalisations.
  • Symptoms typically wax and wane over time.
  • Many patients experience a premonitory urge relieved temporarily by the tic.
  • OCD and ADHD frequently co-occur with Tourette's disorder.

Investigations and Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis based on history and observation of tics.
  • No laboratory test is diagnostic.

Management:

  • Psychoeducation and supportive therapy are key for mild cases.
  • Antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone) may be used for severe tics.
  • CBT techniques like habit reversal training are helpful.

Explanation of Other Options:

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (Option A): Incorrect, as OCD involves intrusive thoughts and compulsions, not involuntary motor/vocal tics, although OCD is often comorbid with Tourette disorder.

Primary Insomnia (Option B): Incorrect because insomnia involves sleep difficulties without the motor and vocal features of tics.

Parkinson's Disease (Option C): Incorrect; Parkinson's disease involves tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia, not sudden, repetitive tics.
